div.head:
An Original Letter from Humboldt—Handsome
Compliment to an American Officer.
div.p:
Washington, Feb. 7, 1857.—In the absence
of anything particularly interesting or impor-
tant in the political world, you and you read-
ers will, I know, be delighted with the treasure
I send you in the shape of an original letter
from the venerable and generated Humboldt.
It has never before been published, and I am
happy to be the medium, through the columns
of the Inquirer, of first communicating it to
the world. It was with considerable difficulty
that I obtained it, owing to the extreme person-
al modesty of its recipient, but I was favored
with a translation in the hands of the House
Committee on Engraving, and send it to you
entire, both because it is a magnificent compli-
ment to a most excellent and deserving man
whose noble services have been ill-requitted by
his Government, and because it contains pas-
sages relative to its author which will be of
general interest everywhere. The autograph
manuscript is extremely interesting and char-
acteristic, and will doubtless be cherished by
its presend possessor as a sort of heirloom.
If pride were ever justifiable, he certainly is
entitled to indulge in it after receiving such a
testimonial from such a source. The following
is a litteral translation of the letter.

“I need words to express to you how much I
have been touched by the noble token of re-
membrance you have sent me—the admirable
volumes you have published on Chili and the
magnificent Cordilleras bordering it. In one
respect your work marks an epoch, for, at the
time of Bougeur and La Condamine, science
was less advanced, and instruments and methods
less perfected. You have enriched at the same
time Astronomy, Geography, Geology, and, to
some extent, descriptive Natural History. A
work which has been brought out in so splen-
did a manner, well merits the title of a “Na-
val Astronomical Expedition of the United
States.” After you, it honors the Government
which undertook and fostered it.

“I have read it at night page by page, and
always with increasing interest; and, although
your generous present reached me at the most
disturbed period of my life, when my health is
no little suffering, I have been able to enjoy it
and express to you my admiration for a work
greatly superior to every thing published upon
South America since the time of Bouguer and
La Condamine. Varied in its delineations,
rich in celestial, magnetical, geographical, and
historical facts, for it all I need a leisure which
is not accorded to me. I should limit myself
to profit by your observations, and, offering to
you from them the most cordial expressions of
gratitude, I hope to live long enough to see the
next volume.

“Tell me, will it contain the extensive astro-
nomical observations for the parallax—the im-
mediate object of your important expedition—
your magnetical observations (the intensity
greatly interests me, from my own investiga-
tions in Peru long ago)—the review of the
Southern heavens; and your report on the bril-
liancy of Eta Argus, which you saw as lumi-
nous as Canopus?

“Although I have passed a portion of my
life in measuring them, I do not regard the
phenomenon of the absolute height of moun-
tains as one of great moment; yet, when called
upon to answer the question, ‘Which is the
highest mountain of America?’ I should be
able to give the numbers that are believed to be
the most exact. Is the highest mountain, then,
Aconcagua, Sahama, or your Tupungato, in
latitude 33 deg. 22 min S.? In the table on
page 13, you state it to be 22,458 feet, and on
the map from the survey of M. Pissis, oppo-
site page 48, only 22,016 feet. Which of these
numbers seems to you the most probable? The
trigonometrical measures seem equally depend-
ent on barometrical valuations of the base.

“Do you consider the result for Aconcagua
by M. Pissis, 22,301 feet, as more reliable than
than that given us by Fitzroy, who made it
21,766 Paris feet? though, according to the
correction by Pentland we should have 22,431
Paris feet. Kellet found Aconcagua to have a
height of 21,567 Parisian, or 23,004 English
feet. To which of these determinations do you
give preference?

“Chimborazo should also be re-measured.
From my observations made at Riobamba-Nuevo,
I believe its elevation to be 20,100 Paris feet.
Kunchingunga is 4,406 toises The brothers
Schlagintwert have been on the slopes of Ibi-
Gamen in Thibet, and found Siberian shells at
an elevation of 20,886 French feet!
